questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient is scheduled for a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, which of the following is not an advantage of laparoscopic surgery? (INICET NOV 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Laparoscopic surgeries result in lesser post-operative pain.

options.label: B
options.text: Laparoscopic surgeries are cosmetically better as they result in smaller incisions.

options.label: C
options.text: Laparoscopic surgeries result in an earlier return to normal physiological function.

options.label: D
options.text: Laparoscopic surgeries result in a longer duration of stay in the hospital

questions.correct_answer: D. Laparoscopic surgeries result in a longer duration of stay in the hospital
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Laparoscopic surgeries result in a longer duration of stay in the hospital

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the Global Hunger Index? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Infant Mortality Rate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Global Hunger Index is calculated based on the following indicators:
  • • Till 2014 – following 3 indicators
  • • After 2016, the Global Hunger Index calculation was done using above four indicators, which do not include the infant mortality rate directly.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. U5MR: Because the under-five mortality rate is one of the four indicators used in the calculation of the Global Hunger Index.
  • • Option
  • • A. U5MR:
  • • Option B. Malnutrition (wasting, stunting): Because both child wasting and child stunting are part of the four indicators used in the calculation of the Global Hunger Index.
  • • Option
  • • B. Malnutrition (wasting, stunting):
  • • Option C. Inadequate food supply: Because, while inadequate food supply can contribute to child undernourishment, it is not directly used as an indicator in the calculation of the Global Hunger Index.
  • • Option
  • • C. Inadequate food supply:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Global Hunger Index is calculated using four indicators: child undernourishment, under-five mortality rate, child wasting, and child stunting. The infant mortality rate is not directly included in the calculation.

questions.text: Which of the following is a tumor marker of carcinoid tumor? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Clinically, patients with carcinoid syndrome may present with a range of symptoms including hepatomegaly, bronchospasm that mimics asthma, episodes of vasoconstriction affecting blood vessels, increased intestinal motility manifesting as diarrhea, and distinctive flushing of the skin. The co-occurrence of symptoms like diarrhea, asthma-like respiratory issues, and hepatomegaly should immediately suggest the possibility of carcinoid syndrome.
  • ➤ An increase in the levels of 5-HIAA in blood and urine is a significant indicator (primary tumor marker) of carcinoid syndrome.

questions.text: Patient had a fall on Outstretched hand. He presented with Fracture and displacement of Base of 1st metacarpal. This fracture is known as: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bennet’s fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A Bennett's fracture involves the base of the first metacarpal with displacement due to muscle pull, often resulting from a fall on an outstretched hand.
  • ➤ A Bennett's fracture involves the base of the first metacarpal with displacement due to muscle pull, often resulting from a fall on an outstretched hand.

questions.text: Amongst the options given below, which of these are not seen in cocaine poisoning? ( INICET May 2022 )

options.label: A
options.text: Tingling and numbness of hands and feet

questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Constricted pupils and bradycardia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Features of cocaine intoxication:
  • ➤ Features of cocaine intoxication:
  • ➤ Early features – Stage of excitement: Dry mouth, dysphagia, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypertension, dilated pupils, and increased temperature followed by convulsions, hallucinations, tingling, and numbness in the hands and feet. Late features – Stage of depression – Respiration is depressed, excessive sweating, collapse, convulsions, and death. Magnan’s symptoms / Cocaine bugs - Chronic cocaine users may have the feeling of insects crawling on their skin or the presence of grains of sand under the skin. Ulceration of nasal septum seen due to sniffing cocaine in chronic abuse
  • ➤ Early features – Stage of excitement:
  • ➤ Early features
  • ➤ Dry mouth, dysphagia, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypertension, dilated pupils, and increased temperature followed by convulsions, hallucinations, tingling, and numbness in the hands and feet.
  • ➤ Late features – Stage of depression – Respiration is depressed, excessive sweating, collapse, convulsions, and death.
  • ➤ Late features
  • ➤ Magnan’s symptoms / Cocaine bugs - Chronic cocaine users may have the feeling of insects crawling on their skin or the presence of grains of sand under the skin.
  • ➤ Ulceration of nasal septum seen due to sniffing cocaine in chronic abuse

questions.text: Elderly male with a 3-week presents with history of trauma, with CT brain image as shown. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) SDH (Subdural Hematoma)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic Subdural Hematoma (SDH) is often seen in elderly patients with a history of minor trauma, presenting weeks after the injury with symptoms such as headache, confusion, or neurological deficits. The characteristic CT finding is a crescent-shaped collection along the convexity of the brain, distinguishing it from other types of intracranial hemorrhages.

questions.text: A female patient with infertility presents with galactorrhea. Evaluation reveals a 7mm prolactinoma. She is worried about her conception chances. What is the appropriate drug in this situation? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Although cabergoline is often used for prolactinomas due to better tolerability and efficacy, it is not the preferred agent when fertility is desired, especially around the time of conception or planned pregnancy.
  • • According to endocrine guidelines:
  • • According to endocrine guidelines:
  • • Bromocriptine has been safely used for over 30 years in women trying to conceive, with no proven teratogenicity.
  • • Once pregnancy is confirmed, bromocriptine is discontinued to reduce fetal exposure.
  • • Cabergoline, being long-acting with high D₂ receptor affinity, is not recommended during conception planning, due to less extensive safety data in pregnancy.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Cabergoline : Not preferred in women desiring fertility due to longer half-life and limited pregnancy safety data.
  • • Option A. Cabergoline
  • • Option C. Octreotide : A somatostatin analog used for GH-secreting tumors (e.g., acromegaly), not prolactinomas.
  • • Option C. Octreotide
  • • Option D. Pegvisomant : GH receptor antagonist for acromegaly; no role in prolactinoma or fertility.
  • • Option D. Pegvisomant

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In women with microprolactinoma and infertility, bromocriptine is the first-line treatment to restore ovulation and promote safe conception. While cabergoline is effective and often better tolerated, it is not the agent of choice when pregnancy is desired, due to concerns regarding its longer action and limited pregnancy safety data.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presented with claudication in the forearm, transient loss of vision, and abdominal pain. Femoral pulses were weak. Fundus examination revealed retinal hemorrhages. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Takayasu arteritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Takayasu arteritis should be considered in young women presenting with symptoms of large vessel occlusion, such as claudication, weak pulses, and ischemic symptoms in various organs. It is characterized by the involvement of the aorta and its major branches, and the diagnosis can be confirmed with imaging studies like CT angiogram or conventional angiography.

questions.text: What of the following stain can be used for staining Iron in tissues? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prussian blue stain is specifically used for detecting iron deposits in tissues, particularly in cases of iron overload or iron-related disorders.

questions.text: A young male child presents with failure to pass meconium and has been diagnosed with megacolon. Which of the following layers is affected by the absence of neurons? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2 and 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hirschsprung disease is characterized by the absence of the submucosal (Meissner's) and myenteric (Auerbach's) plexuses in the submucosa and muscularis propria, leading to functional obstruction and megacolon due to failure of neural crest cell migration.

questions.text: During fetal autopsy, what is the order of examination to differentiate between live and stillbirth ? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Head > Abdomen > Thorax

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During a fetal autopsy, the correct sequence of examination is Head > Abdomen > Thorax, with the abdomen being opened before the thorax to check the diaphragm level for respiration evidence

questions.text: Mother had painful vesicular lesions over genitalia one year back. Baby is born with features of meningitis and fever and rashes in abdomen and forearm and died within a week. Scrapings from lesions showed multinucleate giant cells. What is the most likely organism? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.correct_answer: A. Herpes Simplex Virus type 2 ( HSV2)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Herpes Simplex Virus type 2 (HSV2)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The correct answer is HSV2 (Herpes Simplex Virus Type 2). The clinical history provided in the question strongly suggests neonatal herpes infection. The mother had a history of painful vesicular lesions over the genitalia, which is characteristic of genital herpes caused by HSV2. Neonatal herpes can be transmitted from the mother to the baby during childbirth if the mother has an active HSV infection. The baby presented with symptoms of meningitis, fever, and rash, which are typical manifestations of neonatal herpes. The presence of multinucleated giant cells on scrapings from lesions further supports the diagnosis, as these are characteristic findings in herpes infections.
  • • The correct answer is HSV2 (Herpes Simplex Virus Type 2). The clinical history provided in the question strongly suggests neonatal herpes infection.
  • • The mother had a history of painful vesicular lesions over the genitalia, which is characteristic of genital herpes caused by HSV2.
  • • Neonatal herpes can be transmitted from the mother to the baby during childbirth if the mother has an active HSV infection.
  • • The baby presented with symptoms of meningitis, fever, and rash, which are typical manifestations of neonatal herpes.
  • • The presence of multinucleated giant cells on scrapings from lesions further supports the diagnosis, as these are characteristic findings in herpes infections.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Enterovirus 70:
  • • Option B. Enterovirus 70:
  • • Enterovirus 70 is associated with acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, not with vesicular lesions or the neonatal symptoms described in the question. It does not typically cause multinucleated giant cells in lesions.
  • • Enterovirus 70 is associated with acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, not with vesicular lesions or the neonatal symptoms described in the question.
  • • It does not typically cause multinucleated giant cells in lesions.
  • • Option C. Human Papillomavirus (HPV) :
  • • Option C. Human Papillomavirus (HPV)
  • • HPV causes warts and is associated with genital warts, but it does not cause painful vesicular lesions or neonatal meningitis. HPV also does not produce multinucleated giant cells on lesion scrapings.
  • • HPV causes warts and is associated with genital warts, but it does not cause painful vesicular lesions or neonatal meningitis.
  • • HPV also does not produce multinucleated giant cells on lesion scrapings.
  • • Option D. VZV:
  • • Option D. VZV:
  • • Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV) can cause vesicular lesions, but the clinical scenario described (painful genital lesions in the mother) and the findings in the neonate (multinucleated giant cells and severe systemic symptoms) are more consistent with HSV2 rather than VZV.
  • • Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV) can cause vesicular lesions, but the clinical scenario described (painful genital lesions in the mother) and the findings in the neonate (multinucleated giant cells and severe systemic symptoms) are more consistent with HSV2 rather than VZV.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Herpes Simplex Virus Type 2 (HSV2) is the most likely organism causing neonatal herpes, characterized by the presence of painful vesicular lesions in the mother and severe systemic symptoms including meningitis, fever, and rash in the newborn, along with multinucleated giant cells found in lesion scrapings.
  • ➤ Herpes Simplex Virus Type 2 (HSV2) is the most likely organism causing neonatal herpes, characterized by the presence of painful vesicular lesions in the mother and severe systemic symptoms including meningitis, fever, and rash in the newborn, along with multinucleated giant cells found in lesion scrapings.

questions.text: In a small coastal town in Kerala, a sudden surge of gastroenteritis cases is reported within two days after a community seafood feast. Health officials suspect the seafood feast as the source of the epidemic. Which of the following statements is true regarding this type of single exposure point source epidemic? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Explosive in nature

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Single exposure point source epidemics are explosive in nature with a rapid increase and decline in cases, confined to one incubation period.

questions.text: The appearance of saphenofemoral junction on USG, showing common femoral vein, common femoral artery and the great saphenous vein is called as:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Mickey mouse sign

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Mickey Mouse sign is the normal anatomy of the common femoral artery, common femoral vein and great saphenous vein on ultrasound at the saphenofemoral junction.
  • • common femoral artery, common femoral vein and great saphenous vein
  • • Mickey mouse sign: Normal SFJ
  • • Mickey mouse sign: Normal SFJ
  • • IOC for varicose veins, SFJ incompetence: Doppler USG
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: String sign results from a severe narrowing of a bowel loop , which makes the lumen resemble a string. Seen in case of Pyloric stenosis .
  • • Option A: String sign
  • • severe narrowing of a bowel loop
  • • Pyloric stenosis
  • • Option B: Tillaux sign is positive in the case of mesenteric cyst . It is described as a mass lesion of the abdomen which is only mobile in the horizontal and not in vertical direction.
  • • Option B:
  • • Tillaux sign
  • • mesenteric cyst
  • • Option D: Stemmer sign is seen as non-pitting edema in cases of lymphedema.
  • • Option D:
  • • Stemmer sign
  • • non-pitting edema
  • • in cases of lymphedema.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "Mickey Mouse sign" on ultrasound is a useful anatomical descriptor for the normal configuration of the saphenofemoral junction, aiding in the assessment and diagnosis of venous issues at this location.

questions.text: A comparison is made between the variability present in one dataset and that in another dataset by: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Coefficient of variation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Coefficient of Variation (CV) is the appropriate measure for comparing the relative variability of different datasets because it standardizes the measure of dispersion relative to the mean, allowing for meaningful comparisons across different datasets.

questions.text: Which muscle is affected if the patient is unable to make an "OK" sign? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Flexor pollicis longus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The flexor pollicis longus is essential for making the "OK" sign, and its impairment is a key clinical feature of anterior interosseous nerve damage.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to your clinic for her postpartum checkup. She mentions that she has been exclusively breastfeeding her newborn and is concerned about meeting her own nutritional needs in order to ensure the best for her baby. She asks you about specific nutrient supplementation she might need during this period of lactation. Compared to her pregnancy, which nutrient would you recommend she should pay particular attention to increasing? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vitamin A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ According to the latest Nutritional Guidelines,
  • ➤ According to the latest Nutritional Guidelines,
  • ➤ Requirement in Pregnancy > Lactation → Proteins; Zinc; Folic Acid; Iron Requirement in Lactation > Pregnancy → Vitamin A; Iodine; Vitamin C; Carbohydrates, Calcium Requirement in Pregnancy = Lactation → Vitamin D; Calcium
  • ➤ Requirement in Pregnancy > Lactation → Proteins; Zinc; Folic Acid; Iron
  • ➤ →
  • ➤ Requirement in Lactation > Pregnancy → Vitamin A; Iodine; Vitamin C; Carbohydrates, Calcium
  • ➤ →
  • ➤ Requirement in Pregnancy = Lactation → Vitamin D; Calcium
  • ➤ →

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct for a patient on high dose of penicillin and gentamicin? iNICET NOV 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: TDM is done with penicillin because of narrow therapeutic index

options.label: B
options.text: TDM is done with gentamicin because of narrow therapeutic index

options.label: C
options.text: TDM is done with both because of dangerous side effects

options.label: D
options.text: Both drugs do not need monitoring

questions.correct_answer: B. TDM is done with gentamicin because of narrow therapeutic index
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. TDM is done with gentamicin because of narrow therapeutic index

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM) is crucial for gentamicin due to its narrow therapeutic index and potential for nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity. Penicillin, on the other hand, generally does not require TDM because it does not have a narrow therapeutic index.

questions.text: Aspartate forms which of the following intermediate of TCA cycle: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Oxaloacetate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aspartate an amino acid can be converted to oxaloacetate, an intermediate of the cycle. The conversion of aspartate to oxaloacetate is catalyzed by the enzyme aspartate transaminase.
  • ➤ Therefore, aspartate forms glutamate as an intermediate in the TCA cycle.
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 160
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 160

questions.text: Cardiac oedema and neuropathy are seen in which of the following vitamin deficiencies? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Thiamine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency is characterized by cardiac edema and neuropathy, manifesting as wet beriberi (cardiovascular symptoms) and dry beriberi (neurological symptoms).

questions.text: A person working in an industry for a long time developed progressive breathlessness. The histopathological image of his lung biopsy is given below. What industry was he most likely working in? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Asbestos

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

  • ➤ asbestos bodies
  • ➤ asbestos exposure

  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8 th edition 1306-1307

questions.text: The drug used in chemoradiation in cervical cancer: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cisplatin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cisplatin is the preferred drug used in chemoradiation for cervical cancer because it acts as a radiosensitizer, enhancing the effectiveness of radiation therapy.

questions.text: A partogram of a woman in labor is shown below. Oxytocin infusion has been administered. Mark the best management for the patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cesarean section

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The above partogram suggests that the woman has cephalopelvic disproportion, for which the management would be to perform an emergency caesarean section.
  • • According to the above given partogram, findings are
  • • Cervix is fully dilated Moulding is 2+ = Sutures are overlapped but reducible Station is 3+ Oxytocin infusion administered. Uterine contractions - Adequate. Amniotic fluid - M = Meconium-stained fluid Fetal heart rate – Deceleration = Baby is in distress Descent: Head is 3/5 th palpable; this means that an instrument cannot be applied. For either forceps of vacuum to be applied, the head should not be palpable per abdomen.
  • • Cervix is fully dilated
  • • Moulding is 2+ = Sutures are overlapped but reducible
  • • Station is 3+
  • • Oxytocin infusion administered.
  • • Uterine contractions - Adequate.
  • • Amniotic fluid - M = Meconium-stained fluid
  • • Fetal heart rate – Deceleration = Baby is in distress
  • • Descent: Head is 3/5 th palpable; this means that an instrument cannot be applied. For either forceps of vacuum to be applied, the head should not be palpable per abdomen.
  • • In case of fetal distress, the management is an emergency cesarean section, not instrumental delivery or elective cesarean section.
  • • Cephalopelvic disproportion means there is a disproportion in the fetal head and pelvis. It could be due to a Contracted pelvis or large baby (Macrosomia)
  • • Degrees of Disproportion
  • • Severe degree contracted pelvis: Obstetric conjugate < 7.5 cm Moderate degree: Obstetric conjugate between 7.5 to 9.5 cm Borderline pelvis: Obstetric conjugate measures between 9.5 to 10 cm
  • • Severe degree contracted pelvis: Obstetric conjugate < 7.5 cm
  • • Moderate degree: Obstetric conjugate between 7.5 to 9.5 cm
  • • Borderline pelvis: Obstetric conjugate measures between 9.5 to 10 cm
  • • Obstructed labor is one where despite good uterine contractions, the progressive descent of the presenting part is arrested due to mechanical obstruction. Cephalopelvic disproportion and contracted pelvis are the common causes.
  • • A cesarean section at term is should be done in these cases.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Forceps-assisted delivery: Not suitable because the head is still palpable per abdomen and forceps cannot be applied.
  • • Option A. Forceps-assisted delivery:
  • • Option B. Vacuum-assisted delivery: Not appropriate due to the same reason as above; the head is still palpable per abdomen.
  • • Option B. Vacuum-assisted delivery:
  • • Option C. Oxytocin infusion: Oxytocin infusion is already being administered, and increasing or continuing it won't resolve the issue of cephalopelvic disproportion and fetal distress.
  • • Option C. Oxytocin infusion:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of cephalopelvic disproportion and fetal distress, as indicated by a partogram, the management should be an emergency cesarean section.

questions.text: Name the investigation shown in the given image? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Conventional HSG

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Conventional HSG is a critical diagnostic tool in the assessment of uterine structure and tubal patency, using a radiopaque dye visualized with fluoroscopy, particularly useful in the workup of infertility.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female complains of bone pain for 4 months. Her ALP levels are elevated, but serum calcium and phosphorus levels are normal, and X-ray of the patient is shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Paget's Disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Paget's disease of bone is characterized by bone pain, elevated alkaline phosphatase levels, and normal serum calcium and phosphorus levels, with characteristic X-ray findings such as thickening of the calvarium

questions.text: Non-articular bone pain is differentiated from articular bone pain by:(NEET PG 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: Pain in both active and passive movements

questions.correct_answer: B. Pain in only active movements
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pain in only active movements

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Non-articular pain occurs only during active movements. When both active and passive range of movements are painful, it is due to articular pain.

questions.text: Reliable feature of some dehydration is: ( INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: 2 hours after watching a movie, a patient presented with eye ache and difficulty in vision. The first line of management must be: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Mannitol + Pilocarpine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The first-line management of acute angle-closure glaucoma involves the use of Mannitol to reduce intraocular pressure followed by Pilocarpine to constrict the pupil and prevent further angle obstruction.

questions.text: True about Warburg effect?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.correct_answer: B. Aerobic glycolysis with lactate formation
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Aerobic glycolysis with lactate formation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Warburg effect
  • ➤ Warburg effect
  • ➤ This effect occurs in cancerous cells. This is a paradox from normal in the sense that Cancer cells convert pyruvate to lactate even in the presence of O 2 . This is known as aerobic glycolysis. Energy derived from conversion of pyruvate to lactate is just 2 ATPs , hence rapidly growing cancer cells take up large amount of glucose compared to normal cells. Due to large amount of glucose used, patients have Cachexia (weight loss).
  • ➤ This effect occurs in cancerous cells. This is a paradox from normal in the sense that Cancer cells convert pyruvate to lactate even in the presence of O 2 . This is known as aerobic glycolysis.
  • ➤ aerobic glycolysis.
  • ➤ Energy derived from conversion of pyruvate to lactate is just 2 ATPs , hence rapidly growing cancer cells take up large amount of glucose compared to normal cells. Due to large amount of glucose used, patients have Cachexia (weight loss).
  • ➤ 2 ATPs

References:

  • ↳ Reference : Harper’s 30th ed/pg- 738

questions.text: A diabetic patient was advised exercise by the treating physician. The glucose transporter which is insulin sensitive is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Glut 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the first line of treatment of mastitis in a lactating mother? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dicloxacillin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Beta-lactamase-resistant penicillins are recommended in the treatment of mastitis. These include cloxacillin, dicloxacillin, or flucloxacillin. Erythromycin is given to women who are penicillin-sensitive. Dicloxacillin is often the first choice due to its effectiveness against the common causative organism, Staphylococcus aureus.
  • • Puerperal Mastitis:
  • • Puerperal Mastitis:
  • • Definition: Mastitis is an inflammatory condition of the breast that may occur in breastfeeding women during the puerperium. Pathogenesis: Infants are inoculated by personnel carrying S. aureus and transmit the bacteria to the breastfeeding mother through the nasopharynx. Risk Factors: Maternal age > 30 years Maternal fatigue and stress Sores and cracked nipples History of mastitis after a previous pregnancy Breast engorgement, blocked lactiferous ducts, and milk stasis Etiology: Most cases of mastitis result from infection with S. aureus. Other organisms include coagulase-negative staphylococci, β-hemolytic streptococci, Streptococcus faecalis, Escherichia coli, and other bacteria such as Enterobacter cloacae, Pseudomonas picetti, and Haemophilus influenzae. Diagnosis: Maternal fever (100.4°F or higher) Chills, myalgia, malaise Breast tenderness with associated erythema, usually unilateral Segmental erythema on the breast, typically in the upper, outer quadrant, with variable degrees of induration Palpable, fluctuant mass suggesting a breast abscess should prompt immediate breast ultrasound Milk may be expressed for leukocyte and bacterial counts, though this is not recommended for diagnosing uncomplicated mastitis Treatment: Antibiotics: Dicloxacillin, amoxicillin, or nafcillin, or a first-generation cephalosporin Penicillin Allergy: Erythromycin or vancomycin Duration: Antibiotic therapy should be continued for 10 to 14 days to avoid resistant organisms Breastfeeding: Women should continue breastfeeding, initiating feeds on the unaffected breast and changing the infant's position at different feeds to prevent the development of a breast abscess Symptomatic Relief: Analgesics like ibuprofen or acetaminophen, increased fluid intake, adequate nutrition, cold or warm compresses, and breast support should be provided
  • • Definition: Mastitis is an inflammatory condition of the breast that may occur in breastfeeding women during the puerperium.
  • • Definition:
  • • Pathogenesis: Infants are inoculated by personnel carrying S. aureus and transmit the bacteria to the breastfeeding mother through the nasopharynx.
  • • Pathogenesis:
  • • Risk Factors: Maternal age > 30 years Maternal fatigue and stress Sores and cracked nipples History of mastitis after a previous pregnancy Breast engorgement, blocked lactiferous ducts, and milk stasis
  • • Risk Factors:
  • • Maternal age > 30 years Maternal fatigue and stress Sores and cracked nipples History of mastitis after a previous pregnancy Breast engorgement, blocked lactiferous ducts, and milk stasis
  • • Maternal age > 30 years
  • • Maternal fatigue and stress
  • • Sores and cracked nipples
  • • History of mastitis after a previous pregnancy
  • • Breast engorgement, blocked lactiferous ducts, and milk stasis
  • • Etiology: Most cases of mastitis result from infection with S. aureus. Other organisms include coagulase-negative staphylococci, β-hemolytic streptococci, Streptococcus faecalis, Escherichia coli, and other bacteria such as Enterobacter cloacae, Pseudomonas picetti, and Haemophilus influenzae.
  • • Etiology:
  • • Most cases of mastitis result from infection with S. aureus. Other organisms include coagulase-negative staphylococci, β-hemolytic streptococci, Streptococcus faecalis, Escherichia coli, and other bacteria such as Enterobacter cloacae, Pseudomonas picetti, and Haemophilus influenzae.
  • • Most cases of mastitis result from infection with S. aureus.
  • • Other organisms include coagulase-negative staphylococci, β-hemolytic streptococci, Streptococcus faecalis, Escherichia coli, and other bacteria such as Enterobacter cloacae, Pseudomonas picetti, and Haemophilus influenzae.
  • • Diagnosis: Maternal fever (100.4°F or higher) Chills, myalgia, malaise Breast tenderness with associated erythema, usually unilateral Segmental erythema on the breast, typically in the upper, outer quadrant, with variable degrees of induration Palpable, fluctuant mass suggesting a breast abscess should prompt immediate breast ultrasound Milk may be expressed for leukocyte and bacterial counts, though this is not recommended for diagnosing uncomplicated mastitis
  • • Diagnosis:
  • • Maternal fever (100.4°F or higher) Chills, myalgia, malaise Breast tenderness with associated erythema, usually unilateral Segmental erythema on the breast, typically in the upper, outer quadrant, with variable degrees of induration Palpable, fluctuant mass suggesting a breast abscess should prompt immediate breast ultrasound Milk may be expressed for leukocyte and bacterial counts, though this is not recommended for diagnosing uncomplicated mastitis
  • • Maternal fever (100.4°F or higher)
  • • Chills, myalgia, malaise
  • • Breast tenderness with associated erythema, usually unilateral
  • • Segmental erythema on the breast, typically in the upper, outer quadrant, with variable degrees of induration
  • • Palpable, fluctuant mass suggesting a breast abscess should prompt immediate breast ultrasound
  • • Milk may be expressed for leukocyte and bacterial counts, though this is not recommended for diagnosing uncomplicated mastitis
  • • Treatment: Antibiotics: Dicloxacillin, amoxicillin, or nafcillin, or a first-generation cephalosporin Penicillin Allergy: Erythromycin or vancomycin Duration: Antibiotic therapy should be continued for 10 to 14 days to avoid resistant organisms Breastfeeding: Women should continue breastfeeding, initiating feeds on the unaffected breast and changing the infant's position at different feeds to prevent the development of a breast abscess Symptomatic Relief: Analgesics like ibuprofen or acetaminophen, increased fluid intake, adequate nutrition, cold or warm compresses, and breast support should be provided
  • • Treatment:
  • • Antibiotics: Dicloxacillin, amoxicillin, or nafcillin, or a first-generation cephalosporin Penicillin Allergy: Erythromycin or vancomycin Duration: Antibiotic therapy should be continued for 10 to 14 days to avoid resistant organisms Breastfeeding: Women should continue breastfeeding, initiating feeds on the unaffected breast and changing the infant's position at different feeds to prevent the development of a breast abscess Symptomatic Relief: Analgesics like ibuprofen or acetaminophen, increased fluid intake, adequate nutrition, cold or warm compresses, and breast support should be provided
  • • Antibiotics: Dicloxacillin, amoxicillin, or nafcillin, or a first-generation cephalosporin
  • • Antibiotics:
  • • Penicillin Allergy: Erythromycin or vancomycin
  • • Penicillin Allergy:
  • • Duration: Antibiotic therapy should be continued for 10 to 14 days to avoid resistant organisms
  • • Duration:
  • • Breastfeeding: Women should continue breastfeeding, initiating feeds on the unaffected breast and changing the infant's position at different feeds to prevent the development of a breast abscess
  • • Breastfeeding:
  • • Symptomatic Relief: Analgesics like ibuprofen or acetaminophen, increased fluid intake, adequate nutrition, cold or warm compresses, and breast support should be provided
  • • Symptomatic Relief:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Cefazolin: While cefazolin is a cephalosporin and can be effective, it is not the first-line treatment compared to dicloxacillin for mastitis.
  • • Option B. Cefazolin:
  • • Option C. Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is typically used for more severe infections and is not the first-line treatment for mastitis.
  • • Option C. Ceftriaxone:
  • • Option D. Ampicillin: Ampicillin may be used but is not as effective as dicloxacillin for treating Staphylococcus aureus infections in mastitis.
  • • Option D. Ampicillin:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dicloxacillin is the first-line treatment for mastitis in lactating mothers, especially effective against Staphylococcus aureus.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient is evaluated for primary infertility. Semen analysis shows azoospermia. A testicular biopsy is done and the image is shown below. The shown finding is consistent with? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sertoli cell only syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Sertoli cell only syndrome : The given clinical scenario and the biopsy findings are consistent with the diagnosis of Sertoli cell-only syndrome. Patients with Sertoli cell-only syndrome typically present between the ages of 20 and 40 years with primary infertility. Diagnosis is confirmed through testicular biopsy. The histopathology of the biopsy specimen typically shows seminiferous tubules populated by only Sertoli cells, with thickening of the tubular basement membrane and absence of germ cells, which is characteristic of Sertoli cell-only syndrome.
  • • Sertoli cell only syndrome : The given clinical scenario and the biopsy findings are consistent with the diagnosis of Sertoli cell-only syndrome. Patients with Sertoli cell-only syndrome typically present between the ages of 20 and 40 years with primary infertility. Diagnosis is confirmed through testicular biopsy. The histopathology of the biopsy specimen typically shows seminiferous tubules populated by only Sertoli cells, with thickening of the tubular basement membrane and absence of germ cells, which is characteristic of Sertoli cell-only syndrome.
  • • Sertoli cell only syndrome
  • • The given clinical scenario and the biopsy findings are consistent with the diagnosis of Sertoli cell-only syndrome. Patients with Sertoli cell-only syndrome typically present between the ages of 20 and 40 years with primary infertility. Diagnosis is confirmed through testicular biopsy. The histopathology of the biopsy specimen typically shows seminiferous tubules populated by only Sertoli cells, with thickening of the tubular basement membrane and absence of germ cells, which is characteristic of Sertoli cell-only syndrome.
  • • The given clinical scenario and the biopsy findings are consistent with the diagnosis of Sertoli cell-only syndrome.
  • • Patients with Sertoli cell-only syndrome typically present between the ages of 20 and 40 years with primary infertility.
  • • Diagnosis is confirmed through testicular biopsy.
  • • The histopathology of the biopsy specimen typically shows seminiferous tubules populated by only Sertoli cells, with thickening of the tubular basement membrane and absence of germ cells, which is characteristic of Sertoli cell-only syndrome.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Testicular atrophy : Testicular atrophy may present with decreased testicular volume and could be due to various causes like mumps orchitis, trauma, or varicocele. The histopathological findings would not specifically show the absence of germ cells with the presence of only Sertoli cells.
  • • Option B. Testicular atrophy
  • • Option C. Benign testicular neoplasm : Benign testicular neoplasms would present with a mass in the testis and would show specific neoplastic cells on histopathology rather than the absence of germ cells.
  • • Option C. Benign testicular neoplasm
  • • Option D. Orchitis : Orchitis typically presents with inflammation, pain, and swelling of the testes, and the biopsy would show inflammatory infiltrates rather than the absence of germ cells.
  • • Option D. Orchitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sertoli cell-only syndrome is characterized by primary infertility and azoospermia, with testicular biopsy showing seminiferous tubules populated only by Sertoli cells and absence of germ cells.
  • ➤ Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7910341/
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7910341/

questions.text: Fluid of choice for elective surgery is preferably: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Crystalloid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The preferred fluid for elective surgery is crystalloid due to its efficacy in volume expansion, safety, and cost-effectiveness compared to blood, colloid, or FFP.

questions.text: Organisms entering via enteric route into our body are countered by which cells of the liver? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Kupffer cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kupffer cells are the liver macrophages responsible for countering organisms entering the body via the enteric route.

questions.text: A 7-year-old male was brought to OPD by his mother with reduced hearing since 2 months. On otoscopy, tympanic membrane was observed as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Myringitis Bullosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Myringitis Bullosa should be considered when a patient presents with the acute onset of ear pain accompanied by visible blisters on the tympanic membrane, particularly in the context of a recent upper respiratory infection or influenza-like illness. Management focuses on pain relief and monitoring for resolution, with antibiotics or antivirals tailored to the underlying cause if identified.

questions.text: Which of the following process is responsible for glucose absorption into the intestine?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Secondary active transport

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Glucose is absorbed into the intestine by secondary active transport because this process allows for the efficient uptake of glucose against its concentration gradient.
  • • Secondary active transport involves the coupled movement of two substances across a membrane, where the movement of one substance is dependent on the electrochemical gradient created by the movement of another substance. In the case of glucose absorption in the intestine, the secondary active transport mechanism relies on the sodium gradient created by the sodium-potassium pump.
  • • The process of glucose absorption in the intestine occurs in the brush border membrane of the intestinal epithelial cells, specifically in the small intestine. Here's a step-by-step explanation of how secondary active transport facilitates glucose absorption:
  • • Sodium-Potassium Pump: The sodium-potassium pump actively transports sodium ions (Na+) out of the epithelial cells and into the intercellular space, using ATP energy. This creates a concentration gradient where the sodium concentration is higher outside the cell. Sodium-Glucose Cotransporter: The sodium gradient generated by the sodium-potassium pump is utilized by a specific protein called the sodium-glucose cotransporter (SGLT). This cotransporter binds both sodium ions and glucose molecules on the outer surface of the cell. Co-transport of Sodium and Glucose: As sodium ions bind to the SGLT protein, their movement into the cell down the concentration gradient provides the necessary energy for the simultaneous movement of glucose against its concentration gradient. Glucose is "dragged" along with the sodium ions as they enter the cell. Glucose Transporter: Once inside the epithelial cell, glucose is transported across the basolateral membrane (the inner surface of the cell) and into the bloodstream by facilitated diffusion through a specific glucose transporter called GLUT2.
  • • Sodium-Potassium Pump: The sodium-potassium pump actively transports sodium ions (Na+) out of the epithelial cells and into the intercellular space, using ATP energy. This creates a concentration gradient where the sodium concentration is higher outside the cell.
  • • Sodium-Glucose Cotransporter: The sodium gradient generated by the sodium-potassium pump is utilized by a specific protein called the sodium-glucose cotransporter (SGLT). This cotransporter binds both sodium ions and glucose molecules on the outer surface of the cell.
  • • Co-transport of Sodium and Glucose: As sodium ions bind to the SGLT protein, their movement into the cell down the concentration gradient provides the necessary energy for the simultaneous movement of glucose against its concentration gradient. Glucose is "dragged" along with the sodium ions as they enter the cell.
  • • Glucose Transporter: Once inside the epithelial cell, glucose is transported across the basolateral membrane (the inner surface of the cell) and into the bloodstream by facilitated diffusion through a specific glucose transporter called GLUT2.
  • • Overall, the energy stored in the sodium gradient created by the sodium-potassium pump is used to actively transport both sodium and glucose into the intestinal epithelial cells. This secondary active transport mechanism allows for the absorption of glucose from the intestinal lumen into the bloodstream efficiently, even when the concentration of glucose is higher inside the cell than in the lumen.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Primary active transport : Incorrect because primary active transport involves the direct use of ATP to move substances against their gradient, which does not apply to glucose absorption in this context.
  • • Option A. Primary active transport
  • • Option B. Facilitated diffusion : Incorrect as this method does not involve the active transport of glucose against its concentration gradient; it only allows movement along the gradient.
  • • Option B. Facilitated diffusion
  • • Option C. Simple diffusion : Incorrect because simple diffusion does not involve any transport proteins and occurs only along the concentration gradient, which is not sufficient for glucose absorption in the intestine.
  • • Option C. Simple diffusion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glucose absorption in the intestine occurs via secondary active transport, utilizing the energy from the sodium gradient created by the sodium-potassium ATPase to transport glucose against its concentration gradient. This process is crucial for efficient glucose uptake from the intestinal lumen into the bloodstream.

questions.text: Pseudo P pulmonale is seen in which electrolyte abnormality? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Hypokalemia

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Adenosine

questions.text: Most common pattern of involvement of Pott’s spine is: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Paradiscal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The paradiscal type is most common pattern of involvement followed by central type followed by anterior type followed by the posterior type.
  • ➤ The paradiscal type is most common pattern of involvement followed by central type followed by anterior type followed by the posterior type.
